(intransitive) To get free; to free oneself.
examples: The prisoners escaped by jumping over a wall.
The factory was evacuated after toxic gases escaped from a pipe.

senses.sense: (transitive) To avoid (any unpleasant person or thing); to elude, get away from.
examples: He only got a fine and so escaped going to jail.
The children climbed out of the window to escape the fire.

senses.sense: (intransitive) To avoid capture; to get away with something, avoid punishment.
examples: Luckily, I escaped with only a fine.

senses.sense: (transitive) To elude the observation or notice of; to not be seen or remembered by.
examples: The name of the hotel escapes me at present.

senses.sense: (transitive, computing) To cause (a single character, or all such characters in a string) to be interpreted literally, instead of with any special meaning it would usually have in the same context, often by prefixing with another character.
examples: When using the "bash" shell, you can escape the ampersand character with a backslash.
Brion escaped the double quote character on Windows by adding a second double quote within the literal.

senses.sense: (computing) To halt a program or command by pressing a key (such as the "Esc" key) or combination of keys.
The act of leaving a dangerous or unpleasant situation.
examples: The prisoners made their escape by digging a tunnel.

senses.sense: Leakage or outflow, as of steam or a liquid, or an electric current through defective insulation.
Something that has escaped; an escapee.
A holiday, viewed as time away from the vicissitudes of life.

examples: You forgot to insert an escape in the datastream.

(legal) A written instrument, such as a deed, temporarily deposited with a neutral third party (the escrow agent), by the agreement of two parties to a valid contract. The escrow agent will deliver the document to the benefited party when the conditions of the contract have been met. The depositor has no control over the instrument in escrow.
(legal) In common law, escrow applied to the deposits only of instruments for conveyance of land, but it now applies to all instruments so deposited.
(legal) Money or other property so deposited is also loosely referred to as escrow.

senses.sense: Having the nature of essence; not physical.

(philosophy) The view that objects have properties that are essential to them.

(sociology) The view that all members of certain groups of people (such as those with the same race, gender, age, or sexual orientation) have common, essential traits inherent to the defining feature of the group; (also) behavior or statement(s) that reflect such a view.
(education) The doctrine that there are certain traditional concepts, values, and skills that are essential to society and should be taught to all students.
A lifestyle that seeks to minimize nonessentials in order to focus on what is important.

(transitive) To misrepresent (something) by oversimplifying a summary of its essence.
(transitive) To misrepresent (a characteristic of something) by falsely portraying it as essential to the whole (that is, implying that it defines the whole's essence).
examples: to essentialize race by stereotyping "what Whites do" or "how Blacks think"

senses.sense: That which is established; as a form of government, a permanent organization, business or force, or the place where one is permanently fixed for residence.

senses.sense: (usually with "the") The ruling class or authority group in a society; especially, an entrenched authority dedicated to preserving the status quo. Also Establishment.
examples: It's often necessary to question the establishment to get things done.

senses.sense: The number of staff required to run a department or organisation (often used in the context of healthcare and other public services).
examples: The cancer department has an establishment of 10 doctors and 30 nurses.
